course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Medicinal Chemistry
course.description: This course will introduce the chemistry principles underlying the drug-target interaction and the development of drugs. One of its major topics is the molecular basis of the interaction of medicinal compounds with various biomolecules and the effect of their structure on their therapeutic activities. In addition, this course will discuss the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics properties of therapeutic agents and how these properties are related to their chemical structure. Moreover, another focus of this course is the chemical strategies to discover and optimize lead compounds that can eventually develop into agents of therapeutic values. For CHEM students and students with instructor's approval only.

reviews.author: yo~
reviews.title: Course with interesting content under CHEM
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to Medicinal Chemistry and drug targets
Nucleic acids: Structure and function
Nucleic acids as targets: interference at the DNA and RNA levels
Protein targets: Protein structure and enzyme catalysis, kinetics, and catalytic mechanism
Protein targets: Enzyme inhibition and inactivation
Protein targets: Receptors and signal transduction
Protein targets: Agonists and Antagonists of receptors
Other targets: Transport and structural proteins and non-protein targets
Other targets: protein-protein interaction
------------Mid-Term------------
Pharmacokinetics: absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion
Finding a lead from natural world
Finding a lead from synthetic chemistry and de novo design
Pharmacophore and structure-activity relationships
Optimization of target binding interaction
Optimization of pharmacokinetic properties
Optimization of pharmacokinetic properties (Prodrug)
Case study: Antiviral drugs
------------Final Exam (Non-Cumulative)------------

Mainly discussing drug targets before midterm.
Focus on drug design after midterm.
Content is quite interesting for me.
reviews.comment_teaching: Never attend any lecture but watch lecture videos only. Prof Guo's english accent is not that good but the content is quite easy to understand, especially the parts after the midterm exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% Mid Term Exam
50% Final Exam
Both exam 60% MCs, 40% Short Questions

This year's stats for reference: (High, Low, Mean)/Total
Mid Term Exam: (42, 19, 30.25)/50
Final Exam: (47, 22.5, 36.12)/50
Course grade not yet released (To be updated)
reviews.comment_workload: Very low workload, only midterm and final. Midterm requires more memorization, and need more revision time. The long questions in final exam literally asking the same thing with different structures, making it very easy. The problem sets he uploaded is also helpful for preparing for the types of questions will be tested. (Although you can only obtain the answer by making appointment with Prof Guo)

reviews.author: shang
reviews.comment_content: The content of this course is quite interesting, at least to me. The content of this course can be divided into two parts. The first part is about the targets of drugs and how drugs 'attack' these targets to cure diseases. The second part is about how to discover,optimize a new drug. The whole course has a great emphasis on your proficiency in writing mechanism for organic reaction.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor.GUO is a nice and helpful. Perhaps the only problem is that he is not quite fluent in English and may sometimes make the course a little bit tedious.
reviews.comment_grading: I have heard that the grading is horrible with mean=C+. Anyway, you can get an A+ if you get >=90%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite light if you just want a pass. But you should really push yourself if you want a good grade.
